title: 103_hr929
content: SECTION 1. SIMPLIFICATION OF EMPLOYMENT TAXES ON DOMESTIC SERVICES. Increase in Threshold Requirement for wages defined in the Internal Revenue Code and the Social Security Act from $50 to $300. Coordination of Collection of Domestic Service Employment with Income Taxes under Chapter 25 of the Internal Revenue Code. Coordination of Collection of Domestic Service Employment with Income Taxes is amended by adding a new section to Chapter 25 of the Internal Revenue Code. SEC. 3510: Coordination of collection of domestic service employment taxes with income taxes. The text outlines the general rules for filing returns for domestic service employment taxes on a calendar year basis. Returns must be filed by the 15th day of the fourth month following the close of the employer's taxable year. No deposit requirements apply to these taxes. Domestic service employment taxes are subject to estimated tax provisions for the purpose of section 6654. Domestic service employment taxes are treated as taxes imposed by chapter 2 for the taxable year of the employer. Adjustments may be made in the application of estimated tax provisions under section 6654. For taxable year 1994, a transitional rule increases the amount for estimated tax purposes by 90% of the tax treated under paragraph (1). Domestic service employment taxes refer to taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home. For domestic service in a private home, taxes on remuneration are exempt under certain conditions. This exemption does not apply to employers liable for other employment taxes as determined by the Secretary's regulations. The section does not apply to employers liable for taxes on remuneration for services other than domestic service in a private home. The Secretary has the authority to create regulations for this section and may treat domestic service employment taxes as taxes imposed by chapter 1. Additionally, the Secretary can enter into agreements to collect state unemployment taxes. The Secretary is authorized to enter agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes on remuneration for domestic service in private homes. Taxes collected under these agreements are treated as domestic service employment taxes. The Secretary can enter agreements with states to collect state unemployment taxes on remuneration for domestic service in private homes. Taxes collected under these agreements are treated as domestic service employment taxes and transferred to the State's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. The collected amount is considered a tax imposed by chapter 23 for purposes of subtitle F. The term 'State' is defined as per section 3306(j)(1). The term 'State' in this subsection refers to its definition in section 3306(j)(1) of the Code. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 25. Effective Date: The amendments apply to remuneration paid in calendar years after 1993.
